ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a little bit of good information about drug design, but there was a lot of overlap with what we had already covered in Chem 519.

I learned so much in this class! I think one of the key skills I really improved on because of this course was thinking more critically of information presented to me. For example, the paper presentation forced me to ask more questions that I usually would when I read a paper.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think the course was fairly disorganized, and the exam/problem sets/presentations did not assess what was actually discussed during lecture. I wish we had spent more time discussing specific examples/case studies of drug design and development rather than broad chemical biology concepts that have been covered in other courses. The expectations for the presentations were unclear and inconsistent as Dr. Spiegel opted to change the format after one group had already presented. I don't think there was anything covered in this class that was new or couldn't have been learned from a quick Google search.

The course was lacking in-depth instruction on the various biophysical assays that are used to evaluate ligand-binding such as ITC, SPR, and alpha screen. It would've been great to cover how these experiments work and learn about their strengths and weaknesses.
It covers a broad range of med chem concepts, but many are repetitive with the first half of the quarter in Chem 519

The course had many strengths. For one, I greatly appreciated having the lecture ppt slides before class. In addition, lectures were clear and packed with information. I think the course could be improved with more optional readings. Some papers were uploaded to canvas and I really thought they all aided my understanding of the concepts we learned in class.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: No. The class is incredibly disorganized. Very little new or unique material is presented. Expectations for assignments and assessments are unclear.

No. This class is poorly organized and there is no clear expectations for students, and the rubrics are constantly changing (the would be final exam turned into a final problem set). The lectures are basically contents on the slides, and I did not get any more insights from listening to Dr. Spiegel's lecture. Also, the problem sets and exams had very little to do with the materials we covered in class.
Yes, because this class was a great overview of drug development and design.
